content: The "Strengthening Veterans Health Care Act of 2017" acknowledges the need to address the backlog in healthcare services for veterans and the shortage of healthcare professionals at VA facilities. There are approximately 45,000 vacancies at the Veterans Health Administration, with 36,000 of them being for front line care positions. The "Strengthening Veterans Health Care Act of 2017" addresses the backlog in healthcare services for veterans and the shortage of healthcare professionals at VA facilities. Approximately 45,000 vacancies exist at the Veterans Health Administration, with 36,000 for front line care positions. SEC. 3. APPROPRIATION OF AMOUNTS FOR HEALTH CARE FROM DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The "Strengthening Veterans Health Care Act of 2017" appropriates $5 billion to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire medical staff and increase veterans' access to care without fiscal year limitation. The "Strengthening Veterans Health Care Act of 2017" appropriates $5 billion to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to hire medical staff, including nurses, social workers, mental health professionals, dental professionals, and other healthcare professionals as needed. This funding is allocated for expenses, equipment, and costs associated with hiring primary care physicians, specialty care physicians, and other medical staff to improve veterans' access to care. The "Strengthening Veterans Health Care Act of 2017" appropriates $5 billion to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for hiring medical staff and improving physical infrastructure of the Department, including hospitals, nursing homes, and facilities. This includes contracts for repairs, leases, and minor construction projects. A report is required within one year. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to Congress within one year on how the appropriated funds have been used. The report must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs and the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate, as well as the Committee on Veterans' Affairs and the Committee on Appropriations of the House of Representatives. Additionally, the Secretary is required to provide a funding plan to Congress outlining how the funds will be utilized. The Secretary must submit a funding plan to Congress detailing the use of appropriated funds. The Act is designated as an emergency requirement under the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 and the Senate's concurrent resolution on the budget for fiscal year 2010.
